0:
Internet is ubiquitous now with 3 billion users and 1 billion web sites.
Let's look at how fast it happened.

To start or navigate manually, use buttons below or arrows/space keys.
1990:
We start in 1990, when the all the core technologies of the Internet -
HTTP, HTML, Web Browser and Web Server - were ready.
First high-speed cable between Europe and America was installed to replace satellite connection.
2.6M people were using Internet protocol to connect to networks, but these networks were separated.
1991:
World Wide Web, initially developed in CERN by Tim Berners-Lee,
was opened to public, linking individual networks into a global information space.
First web site was launched. You can see how it looked back then.
1992:
The Internet Society (ISOC) was founded to help standardize Internet -
the system that we use to access the Web.
1993:
CERN agreed that anyone could use their Web protocol and code royalty-free.
By the end of 1993 there were 623 web sites.
1994:
World Wide Web Consortium (W3C) -
the main international web standards organization was formed.
1995:
JavaScript - the language of the Web was created by Brendan Eich.
oogle was founded by two Stanford University PhD students,
Larry Page and Sergey Brin, as a research project.
1996: Developing countries - Brazil, India, Russia, and South Africa are in top-20 by Internet users.
1997:
1.5% of the world has Internet access.
That's 116 million people.
1998: For the first time, more people were using Internet outsite the US than inside.
1999:
The term "Web 2.0" was coined to anticipate the rise of interactivity,
social media and user-generated content.
2000:
More than $300 billion was spent over the world to address the Y2K problem.
Very few problems were encountered, despite the hype.
There's also the Y10K problem to prepare.
2001:
Burst of the Dot-com bubble.
Between 2000 and 2002, NASDAQ companies lost 75% of their market value - $5 trillion.
Wikipedia was also founded in 2001.
2002:
There are 3 millon sites on the web.
95% of the users use Internet Explorer as their browser.
2003:
China took second place in Internet users.
YAHOO! is the year's most visited site, previously it was AOL.
2004:
oogle went public with market value of $23B.
acebook was founded on the Harvard campus.
2005: More than a billion people use Internet.
2006: One person managed to connect to the Web using a typewriter.
2007:
Apple's first iPhone was released.
One particular internet-meme occured for the first time and soon became a bit too popular.
2008:
For the first time, more people used Internet in China than in the US.
oogle became the top site on the web.
2009: 20% of the world uses the Internet.
2011:
During a single day of October 31st, 2011, 1 billion messages was sent using WhatsApp.
During the year, Youtube videos were played a trillion times.
2012:
acebook went public, with valuation of $104B.
This is a very unusual amount for a tech company.
Psy's Gangnam Style video was the first to pass a billion views on YouTube.
2013: 30% of the world has Internet access.
2014:
Almost 3 billion people are using the Internet - that is every third person, and there are a billion web-sites.
As of 2015, in the US, there are more mobile-only internet users than desktop-only.
2015:
Some of the Internet themes that we can expect to bloom very soon are:
Internet of things, virtual and augmented reality,
and web-based services that will disrupt traditional business models.
Dream big!
